title: How it works
text: PhenoMeNals integrates eco-physiological signals across grapevine phenological cycle predict yield quality traits. section explains underlying biological logic modeling steps. ğŸ§  Recommended advanced users researchers interested model structure ecophysiological logic. Grapevine phenology cornerstone yield quality prediction, environmental conditions across two growing seasons influence reproductive development. Traditional forecasting models often focus single seasons fixed time windows, overlooking cumulative effects. PhenoMeNals addresses gap phenology-aware framework integrates: ğŸŒ± Phenology simulation using BBCH observations weather data ğŸŒ¡ï¸ Eco-physiological functions capturing temperature, radiation, water balance, stress signals ğŸ“Š Statistical modeling cumulative environmental effects (memory signals) yield quality Validated across multi-site, multi-variety datasets, PhenoMeNals consistently achieved RÂ² > 0.8 yield, yield components, quality traits. ğŸ“„ See full description PhenoMeNals paper:PhenoMeNals framework grapevine yield quality prediction (Bregaglio & Bajocco, 2025)  Figure 1. Overview PhenoMeNals workflow. pipeline integrates BBCH observations weather data calibrate phenological model reproducing grapevine cycle across two seasons (Year -1 Year 0). Eco-physiological functions computed along timeline aggregated within phenological bins. signal evaluated correlation target trait normalized via sigmoid transformation. resulting cumulative memory signals (PhenoMeNals) serve predictors Leave One Cross Validation (LOOCV) using multiple linear regression. Outputs include regression coefficients, variable importance model diagnostics. PhenoMeNals organizes workflow along full two-season grapevine cycle:

title: How it works
text: Eight eco-physiological functions computed along standardized phenological timeline. functions translate weather variables biologically meaningful indices, normalized 0 (inhibitory) 1 (optimal). function parameterized using literature values, uncertainty bands representing inter-study variation. functions calculated hourly, aggregated daily, normalized. serve potential predictors downstream modeling. See figure  Photoperiodic unit dormancy induction. shades correspond 40-60th 25-75th percentiles distribution generated limiting photoperiod ranging 12 14.5 hours non limiting photoperiod 11.5 13 hours.

text: TempF={0if T<Tmin T>Tmax(Tmaxâˆ’TTmaxâˆ’Topt)â‹…(Tâˆ’TminToptâˆ’Tmin)(Toptâˆ’TminTmaxâˆ’Topt)otherwise \text{TempF} = \begin{cases} 0 & \text{} T < T_{\text{min}} \text{ } T > T_{\text{max}} \\ \left( \frac{T_{\text{max}} - T}{T_{\text{max}} - T_{\text{opt}}} \right) \cdot \left( \frac{T - T_{\text{min}}}{T_{\text{opt}} - T_{\text{min}}} \right)^ { \left( \frac{T_{\text{opt}} - T_{\text{min}}}{T_{\text{max}} - T_{\text{opt}}} \right)} & \text{otherwise} \end{cases} equation simulates nonlinear temperature response plant growth using cardinal temperatures: minimum (Tmin), optimum (Topt), maximum (Tmax). Growth rate peaks Topt zero outside Tminâ€“Tmax range.

text: DiseaseF={1if WD>WDopt0if WD<WDminWDmin/f(T)WDoptotherwise \text{DiseaseF} = \begin{cases} 1 & \text{} WD > WD_{\text{opt}} \\ 0 & \text{} WD < WD_{\text{min}} \\ \frac{WD_{\text{min}} / f(T)}{WD_{\text{opt}}} & \text{otherwise} \end{cases} Evaluates infection risk P. viticola based temperature suitability wetness duration. Uses temperature response TempF.

title: How it works
text: eco-physiological signal : Smoothed using rolling mean (default: 3 days) Discretized along 0â€“400 phenological timeline (default: 1-bin resolution) alignment captures biological stages rather calendar dates. Pairwise correlations among signals computed detect multicollinearity. Signals r > 0.9 screened, least redundant signal retained. binâ€™s correlation target traits (e.g., yield, brix) evaluated using Pearsonâ€™s r associated p-value. Trait values minâ€“max normalized within siteâ€“variety combination [â€“1, 1], generating correlation profile across phenological cycle.

what: 3. Sigmoid Scaling, Weighting, and Signal Aggregation
title: How it works
text: Smoothed signals normalized using sigmoid transformation: f_i: Signal value year fÌƒ: Median value across years bin f_10, f_90: 10th 90th percentiles , signals weighted correlation strength: Finally, weighted signals summed across bins produce cumulative PhenoMeNals:
code: scaled_i = 1 / (1 + exp(-10 * (f_i - fÌƒ) / ((f_90 - f_10) / 2))) weighted_i = scaled_i * r * (1 - p) PhenoMeNal_{i,j} = Î£ weighted_{i,j}(bin) for bin = 1 to 400

title: How it works
text: stepwise variable selection using AIC (via stepAIC MASS package) identifies informative subset PhenoMeNals per bin (max predictors: 4). bin: multiple linear regression model trained using selected PhenoMeNals Leave-One-Cross-Validation (LOOCV) applied (caret package) Metrics computed include RÂ², RMSE, MAE, nMBE Predictor importance assessed using LMG method (Groemping, 2006), decomposes RÂ² averaging contributions across possible predictor orderings. Diagnostic plots include predictionâ€“observation correlation, residual analysis, phenologyâ€“prediction alignment.

title: Phenology Calibration with PhenoMeNals
text: data frame containing hourly daily weather data. function supports flexible column names (aliases automatically detected). Notes:
code: For daily data, only Tmax, Tmin, Precipitation and Latitude are strictly required. For hourly data, only Temperature, Precipitation, Hour, DateTime and Latitude are required. If RelativeHumidity or Radiation are missing, they are automatically estimated using Tmax, Tmin, precipitation, and latitude.

text: nested list model parameters. list typically loaded phenomenalsParameters can customized. Structure: Notes:
code: list[   species][[class]][[parameter]] = list(     min = <minimum calibration value>,     max = <maximum calibration value>,     value = <default value>,     calibration = <TRUE/FALSE>   ) Parameters marked with calibration = TRUE are optimized during calibration. The list is automatically exported to the correct CSV format for the C# engine; you do not need to handle file conversions.

title: Phenology Calibration with PhenoMeNals
text: Calibrated parameters Carmenere ColliOrientali calibrated parameters within defined bounds. ğŸ¯ However, parameter close minimum maximum limit, â€™s good practice slightly expand calibration range re-run process. helps avoid boundary effects ensures optimization isnâ€™t artificially constrained. ğŸ“ Tip: Parameters like bbch65 bbch85 consistently hit edge range may indicate biological assumptions need refining, calibration iterations needed.
code: filtered_params <- calib_result$parameters |>   dplyr::filter(site == "colliorientali", variety == "carmenere")  knitr::kable(filtered_params, caption = "Calibrated parameters for Carmenere at ColliOrientali")

title: Phenology Calibration with PhenoMeNals
text: show time series predicted BBCH stages time. phenologyCalibration() function successfully fits thermal stress-based parameters reproduce observed BBCH stages. calibrated output can now passed runPhenomenals() trait modeling.
code: p<-ggplot(calib_result$phenology |>           mutate(Date=as.Date(Date,format='%m/%d/%Y'),                 year=year(Date)),aes(x=Date)) +    geom_line(aes(y=BBCHPhase))+   geom_point(aes(y=BBCHRef))+   theme_classic()+   geom_line(aes(y=ChillState),col='blue4') ggplotly(p)

what: ğŸ”¥ Correlation heatmap across the two-year cycle
title: Trait Prediction with PhenoMeNals
code: # Start from runPhenomenals output correlations <- phenomenals_result$selection$correlations   ggplot(correlations,        aes(x = cyclePerc, y = cor, fill = cor)) +   geom_col(linewidth = 0.2) +   scale_fill_gradient2(     low = "red",     mid = "white",     high = "blue",     midpoint = 0,     limits = c(-.8, .8),       # full correlation range     name = "Pearson r"   ) +   theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +   facet_wrap(~ecoFunction, ncol = 1) +   theme(     legend.position = "top",     panel.grid = element_blank(),     strip.text = element_text(size = 14),     plot.margin = margin(5, 5, 5, 5)   ) +   labs(x = NULL, y = NULL)

what: ğŸŒŠ Phenomenals dynamics over the cycle (per year)
title: Trait Prediction with PhenoMeNals
code: # Predictions table (carry both normalized + original scale) predictions <- phenomenals_result$results$predictions  # Long format (rename AridityF -> DroughtF for consistency) pred_long <- predictions %>%   tidyr::pivot_longer(AridityF:WindF, names_to = "phenomenals", values_to = "value") %>%   mutate(phenomenals = recode(phenomenals, "AridityF" = "DroughtF"))  ggplot(pred_long) +   stat_summary(fun.data ='mean_se',aes(x = cyclePerc, y = value, fill = phenomenals),                geom = "ribbon", alpha = 0.5) +   stat_summary(fun.data ='mean_se', aes(x = cyclePerc, y = value, color = phenomenals),                geom = "line") +   facet_grid(phenomenals ~ harvest_year, scales = "free", switch = "y") +   scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(200, 400,200)) +   labs(x = "Phenological completion", y = NULL) +   theme(legend.position = "none")

what: ğŸ“ˆ Observed vs simulated trait over years
title: Trait Prediction with PhenoMeNals
code: pred <- phenomenals_result$results$predictions diag <- phenomenals_result$results$diagnostics  # One row per (target, variety, year) w/ diagnostics attached pred_final <- pred %>%   group_by(target, variety, harvest_year) %>%   slice_tail() %>%   ungroup() %>%   left_join(     diag %>% group_by(site, target, variety) %>% slice_tail() %>% ungroup(),     by = c("site", "variety", "target", "cyclePerc")   ) %>%   mutate(     variety_acr = toupper(str_sub(variety, 1, 3)),     target = factor(target, levels = c("yield")),     facet_label = paste0(       variety_acr, " | RÂ² CV=", round(R2_loocv, 2),       " | RÂ²=", round(R2_full, 2)     )   )  ggplot(pred_final) +   geom_col(aes(harvest_year, target_original, color = target,fill=target), linewidth = .5) +   geom_point(aes(harvest_year, prediction_original, fill = target), fill = 'blue',              shape = 21, size = 4, stroke = 0.7, alpha = .8)+   ylab('yield (kg plant-1)') #> Warning: Removed 3 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range #> (`geom_col()`).

what: ğŸ“ˆ Observed vs simulated trait over phenological bins
title: Trait Prediction with PhenoMeNals
code: diagnostics<-phenomenals_result$results$diagnostics |>    mutate(     cyclePerc_f = factor(cyclePerc, levels = sort(unique(cyclePerc))),     var_site_target = paste(variety, site, target, sep = " | ")   )  ggplot(diagnostics, aes(x = cyclePerc)) +   geom_line(aes(y = R2_loocv), color = "red", linewidth = 0.7) +   geom_line(aes(y = RMSE_loocv), color = "blue", linewidth = 0.4) +   scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 1)) +   geom_vline(xintercept = 200, linetype = "dashed", color = "black") +   annotate("text", x = 100, y = 0.95, label = "Year -1", fontface = "italic", size = 4) +   annotate("text", x = 300, y = 0.95, label = "Year 0", fontface = "italic", size = 4) +   annotate("text", x = 50, y = 0.9, label = "Dormancy", color = "gray30", size = 3.5) +   annotate("text", x = 250, y = 0.9, label = "Dormancy", color = "gray30", size = 3.5) +   annotate("text", x = 150, y = 0.9, label = "Growing", color = "gray30", size = 3.5) +   annotate("text", x = 350, y = 0.9, label = "Growing", color = "gray30", size = 3.5) +   # Titoli e tema   labs(     x = "Phenological bin",     y = "Performance metrics",     linetype = NULL,     shape = NULL   ) +   theme_bw()

title: Phenology memory signals
text: PhenoMeNals phenology-aware predictive framework grapevine yield quality forecasting, integrating phenology simulation, eco-physiological functions, statistical modeling. framework explicitly accounts two-year reproductive cycle grapevine, combining dormancy-forcing phenology model cumulative â€œmemory signalsâ€ derived environmental cues (temperature, radiation, water status, biotic abiotic stresses). signals aligned along standardized phenological timeline weighted correlation yield- quality-related traits, enabling biologically meaningful predictions interpretation carry-effects. Note: PhenoMeNals released R package C# routines invoked R. currently available Windows, cross-platform compatibility development.

title: Phenology memory signals
text: ğŸ‡ Predicts grapevine yield quality using phenology-aware environmental signals ğŸ§  Integrates phenology simulation, eco-physiological functions, statistical modeling ğŸ“ˆ Accurate forecasting across multiple sites, varieties, years ğŸ” Analyzes carry-effects yield quality âš™ï¸ Hybrid architecture: R interface + C# computation ğŸªŸ Windows-(Mac/Linux support coming soon)

code: phenologyCalibration(   weather_data,   referenceBBCH,   phenomenalsParameters,   start_year = 2000,   end_year = 2025,   sites = "all",   varieties = "all",   iterations = 100,   timestep = "daily" )

title: Run phenologyCalibration â€” phenologyCalibration
text: weather_data data frame containing hourly weather data. Must include following columns: Latitude, Longitude, DateTime (POSIXct character), Temperature (Â°C), Precipitation (mm), RelativeHumidity (%), Radiation (MJ/mÂ²), WindSpeed (m/s). referenceBBCH data frame containing BBCH phenological observations. Must include: Variety, Site, Latitude, Longitude, Date, BBCH phenomenalsParameters nested list model parameters (usually loaded phenomenals::phenomenalsParameters), structured list[species][[class]][[parameter]], parameter list : min: Minimum calibration value (numeric) max: Maximum calibration value (numeric) value: Default value used simulation (numeric) calibration: Logical; TRUE parameter subject calibration can start phenomenals::phenomenalsParameters modify needed. list automatically converted CSV format required C# executable. start_year first year simulation calibration period (default 2000). end_year last year simulation calibration period (default 2025). sites character vector site names (e.g., "ColliOrientali"). Defaults "site1" provided. varieties character vector variety names include calibration (default: ""). iterations Number iterations simplex (default: 100). timestep Time step input weather data; must "hourly" (default) "daily".

title: Run phenologyCalibration â€” phenologyCalibration
text: named list data frames containing model outputs, loaded output CSV files generated Phenomenals executable. names list entries correspond output file names (without .csv).

title: Run phenomenals â€” runPhenomenals
text: function runs Phenomenals method passing weather data target traits (e.g., yield, Brix, sugar) directly R underlying C# executable. Users need manage configuration files binaries manually. paths execution logic handled internally, core settings exposed.

title: Run phenomenals â€” runPhenomenals
code: runPhenomenals(   weather_data,   target_data,   phenomenalsParameters,   start_year = 2000,   end_year = 2025,   sites = "all",   varieties = "all",   timestep = "daily",   target_traits = c("yield"),   rolling_window = 5,   evaluation_range = list(c(0, 200)),   multicollinearity_threshold = 0.8,   max_phenomenals = 4,   bin_size = 1 )

title: Run phenomenals â€” runPhenomenals
text: weather_data data frame containing hourly weather data. Must include following columns: Latitude, Longitude, DateTime (POSIXct character), Temperature (Â°C), Precipitation (mm), RelativeHumidity (%), Radiation (MJ/mÂ²), WindSpeed (m/s). target_data data frame containing target data (e.g., yield, brix, berry number, malic acid). dataframe must include: Site, Latitude, Longitude, Variety, Year, Variable, Value, Unit. phenomenalsParameters nested list model parameters (usually loaded phenomenals::phenomenalsParameters), structured list[species][[class]][[parameter]], parameter list : min: Minimum calibration value (numeric) max: Maximum calibration value (numeric) value: Default value used simulation (numeric) calibration: Logical; TRUE parameter subject calibration can start phenomenals::phenomenalsParameters modify needed. list automatically converted CSV format required C# executable. start_year first year simulation calibration period (numeric, default 2000). end_year last year simulation calibration period (numeric, default 2025). sites character vector site names (e.g., "ColliOrientali"). varieties character vector variety names include calibration (default: ""). timestep Time step input weather data; must "daily" (default) "hourly". target_traits target traits applying phenomenals (default "yield"). rolling_window window pane size phenomenals smoothing (default 5 days). evaluation_range list numeric vectors specifying percentage range plant cycle compute phenomenals (0â€“200; 0â€“100 = dormancy, 101â€“200 = growing season). (default list(c(0,200))) multicollinearity_threshold threshold consider phenomenals multicorrelations unit cycle percentage (default 0.8). max_phenomenals maximum number phenomenals retain (default 4). bin_size range cycle percentage aggregate phenomenals (default 1).

title: Run phenomenals â€” runPhenomenals
text: named list three components: data Raw processed phenological signals selection Results signal selection (correlation, multicollinearity, stepwise) results Model diagnostics, predictions, coefficients, variable importance

title: Run phenomenals â€” runPhenomenals
